title: How are habits formed: Modelling habit formation in the real world
source_type: Journal Article (European Journal of Social Psychology)
summary: Habits form through repetition in a consistent context. The time to reach automaticity varies wildly (18 to 254 days), with a median of 66 days. Missing a single opportunity does not materially affect the habit formation process.

effectiveness_metrics.description: Demonstrates that consistency over time is more important than intensity or perfection.

mechanisms.name: Asymptotic Automaticity
mechanisms.description: Habit strength increases steeply at first and then plateaus; early repetition is crucial.

mechanisms.name: Context-Dependence
mechanisms.description: Behaviors must be performed in the *same* situation (time/place) to become automatic.

mechanisms.name: Forgiveness Principle
mechanisms.description: Occasional omissions do not derail the process, debunking the 'don't break the chain' perfectionism.

actionable_strategies.name: Consistency Anchor Template
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Ask user to link the app usage to a rock-solid existing habit (e.g., 'After I open my laptop', 'After I pour coffee').

actionable_strategies.name: Forgiving Streak Logic
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Design the streak system to allow 1-2 'skip days' per week without resetting to zero, aligning with the finding that one miss doesn't kill the habit.
